title: Move-In
details:
First-year and transfer students should plan to move into their residence on Friday, August 17, 2012. Due to the large number of students checking in to North Campus, Collegetown (Cascadilla and Sheldon Court), and West Campus on that day, students assigned to those communities are given a move-in time based on the first letter of their last name.
Last name begins with: Arrive between the hours of:

A-G: 8:00am - 11:00am
H-O: 11:00am - 2:00pm
P-Z: 2:00pm-5:00pm

In order to facilitate a smooth move-in experience for everyone, students who arrive early will NOT be able to move in before their assigned move-in time. If you cannot check in during your move-in time, please contact the Housing Office prior to Orientation at housing@cornell.edu. Transfer students assigned to 112 Edgemoor, Schuyler House, and 122 McGraw Place may move in any time between 8:00am and 5:00pm on Friday, August 17.

title: New Student Check-In
details:
You are required to attend New Student Check-In to pick up your Cornell ID Card. If your move-in time is 2:00pm-5:00pm, plan to attend New Student Check-In before moving in. Staff from more than 30 university departments will be available to answer questions and share information about the wealth of programs and services offered at the University. Families are welcome. Seating and concessions are available if you need a break on a busy Move-In Day! To make sure you are ready for Check-In, follow these easy steps:

1. Activate your Cornell NetID and email address.
2. Complete your matriculation. Log in to your To Do List at newstudents.cornell.edu and make sure all required items are complete.
3. Check to make sure you have no holds preventing your University Registration. To be registered you must settle all financial accounts including current semester tuition, satisfy New York State and University health requirements, and have no additional holds. Beginning August 14, log in to Student Center at studentcenter.cornell.edu to check for holds.

title: Community Center Programs Welcome
location: 1st Floor, Robert Purcell Community Center (RPCC) and outside RPCC
details: Move-In Day is here! Community Center Programs (CCP) wants to help you and your parents and siblings to relax and refresh on this big day. We're featuring games, crafts, beach balls, frisbees, cookie decorating, popcorn, and refreshments. We'll also have our Wii and Kinect systems for you to use.

title: The Cornell Store Computer Showcase
details: All students are invited to evaluate or to purchase computer hardware and software at exclusive academic discounts. The showcase is hosted by the Cornell Store's Technology Connection, an authorized campus distributor of technology products from Apple, Dell, Adobe, and Microsoft.

title: Library Tours of Olin, Kroch, and Uris
details: See page 54 of the Orientation Guide for more information.

title: Introduction to Library Research
details: See page 55 of the Orientation Guide for more information.

title: Introduction to  American Academic Libraries
details: See page 55 of the Orientation Guide for more information.

title: Career Services Already?
location: Kaufmann Auditorium, G64 Goldwin Smith Hall
details: Come learn why students might want to look to the future...now. You'll learn about the many programs that Cornell Career Services offers to help students clarify career interests, explore options, and land internships, jobs, or spots in graduate school.

title: Swim Test
location: Men in Teagle Hall, Women in Helen Newman Hall
details: See page 5 of the Orientation Guide for more information.

title: Library Tours of Olin, Kroch, and Uris
details: See page 54 of the Orientation Guide for more information.

title: Money Matters
details: This informative presentation will address topics ranging from bursar bills, the CornellCard, and Big Red Bucks to general financial aid questions. Sponsored by the University Bursar, Campus Life, and the Office of Financial Aid and Student Employment. This session is also offered on Saturday at 2:00pm.

title: Meet the Greeks
location: Lewis Auditorium, G76 Goldwin Smith Hall
details: Cornell is host to one of the nation's premier fraternity and sorority communities, boasting membership of about a third of the undergraduate student body. This session is an opportunity to learn more about fraternities and sororities and meet current Greek community student leaders and staff from the Office of Fraternities, Sororities, and Independent Living.

title: Library Tours of Olin, Kroch, and Uris
details: See page 54 of the Orientation Guide for more information.

title: Student Disability Services Reception
location: 1st Floor Conference Room, 105 Robert Purcell Community Center
details: Take time out of your busy Move-In Day to meet the staff of Student Disability Services. For students with disabilities, learning about the accommodation process is an important part of academic success. In this session we will provide an overview of our services and the procedure for using accommodations. We will discuss resources available on campus to promote academic achievement and strategies for parents to support their students at Cornell.

title: President's Welcome Reception
details: Students are welcome to bring their families to meet President David J. Skorton under the big tent on Rawlings Green located near Court Hall and Helen Newman Hall on North Campus. Enjoy light refreshments at this casual reception with the president, other university administrators, faculty, and staff.

title: The Cornell Shabbat Experience
details: Relax after move-in and get your first taste of the Cornell Shabbat Experience! Enjoy a Shabbat meal and an a cappella performance, meet lots of new people, and hear from upper-class students about their experiences at Cornell. Dinner will be catered by 104 West, Cornell's kosher/multicultural dining hall. Parents and families are welcome! RSVPs preferred; walk-ins accommodated. Please visit our website, hillel.cornell.edu, or call 607.255.4227. There is a fee associated with this event.

title: Resident Advisor (RA) Meeting #1
location: North Campus and Collegetown Residents - See your RA for location
details: It's your first night with your new roommates, suitemates, hallmates, and floormates. The first meeting with your RA will hit the highlights of house rules and expectations for behavior, as well as give you a chance to get to know one another. This is a great time to ask questions and hear realistic answers. Relax, it's fun. Just think, you are all in the same boat, so share the ride together.

title: First-Year Students Meet with Orientation Leader (OL) #1
details: Right after you get to know the people who you are living with on your floor, you'll have the opportunity to get to know some students from your college. Your Orientation Leader (OL) will leave a welcome letter on your door and will start picking up students from their rooms at 9:00pm (don't worry, it may take them as much as half an hour to get to your door, so please stay in your room). Your OL is an upper-level student who is trained to be your personal host, your very own guide, as you begin your time at Cornell. Bring your Orientation Guide and a pen to the meeting to make notes and plan your week.

title: Transfer Students Meet with Orientation Leader (OL) #1
details:
Welcome! Meet your fellow transfer students and get to know each other before Orientation Week really gets rolling. Be sure to grab a copy of the Transfer Orientation Schedule from your OL. It's filled with additional events throughout Orientation that are just for transfer students. Please bring your Orientation Guide and a pen to the meeting and meet your OL in the following locations:

AAP: Lobby of Willard Straight Hall
HOTEL: Art Gallery, Willard Straight Hall
ARTS: Between Bethe & Flora Rose House
HUMEC: International Lounge, Willard Straight Hall
CALS: Noyes Community Recreation Center
ILR: In Front of Keeton House, West Campus
ENG: Lobby of Willard Straight Hall

title: Transfer First Night
details: Make the best of your first night on the hill in the Memorial Room in Willard Straight Hall with some great food and good conversation. Get acquainted with your fellow transfers while enjoying FREE food from the best restaurants in Ithaca. Come, grab a bite to eat, and stay for a while to chat with new friends!

title: First-Year First Night
details: First Night is a lasting Cornell tradition, in which the Class of 2016 will unite for the first time in the Court-Kay-Bauer Quad on North Campus. A comedian will take the stage to kick-off Orientation, but be sure to also stick around for the awesome act that follows! This is a night full of fun, memories, and the opportunity to meet the Class of 2016!

title: Alumni Families and Legacy Reception
details: Family members who are Cornell alumni, entering Cornellians (that's you), and students who have any Cornell ancestors are all cordially invited for juice, coffee, and pastries before New Student Convocation. Sponsored by Alumni Affairs and Development.

title: Department of Music Auditions
details: To learn more about the Music Department auditions, including how to sign up, please visit: music.cornell.edu/performing/auditions-information. You can learn all that you need to know about the vast opportunities within the Department of Music from vocal ensembles and orchestras to individual lessons and various musical ensembles. Audition dates vary by organization; please visit the website for current information and to sign up for an audition time.

title: New Student Convocation
details:
This will be your official welcome from President David J. Skorton, as well as from your student body president and other key student leaders in Schoellkopf Stadium. Please note that it takes 30 minutes to walk to Schoellkopf Stadium from North Campus and 20 minutes from West Campus; please plan accordingly.
If you are notified after you arrive that Convocation is moved indoors because of extreme weather, please report to the following bad-weather locations based on your college affiliation:

Bailey Hall: Agriculture and Life SciencesBarton Hall: Arts & Sciences, Engineering, and ILRCall Auditorium, Kennedy Hall: Human EcologyStatler Auditorium, Statler Hall: Architecture, Art & Planning and Hotel Administration

title: Welcome to Olin and Uris Libraries
details: See page 55 of the Orientation Guide for more information.

title: Dump & Run Sale
details: This annual sale is a green way to stock up on items for your new room. Consider shopping here first and see what you can reuse to reduce harm to the environment. All proceeds go to charity.

title: The Cornell Store Computer Showcase
details: All students are invited to evaluate or to purchase computer hardware and software at exclusive academic discounts. Hosted by the Cornell Store's Technology Connection, an authorized campus distributor of technology products from Apple, Dell, Adobe, and Microsoft.

title: Big Red Marching Band Auditions
details: Informal auditions for the only REAL marching band in the Ivy League! Meet current members. Any and all majors welcome. No experience necessary, and school instruments are available to use. More information can be found online at mb.bigredbands.org.

title: Introduction to Library Research
details: See page 55 of the Orientation Guide for more information.

title: Take a Hike with Friends of the Gorge (throughout the afternoon)
location: Meet outside the Tatkon Center, the Beebe Lake side
details: Cornell's campus is known for its natural beauty, but many students never get the chance to fully appreciate all the gorges have to offer. Join Friends of the Gorge on a scenic walk around Fall Creek Gorge and Beebe Lake. Come relax, meet some new people, explore your campus, and enjoy the beautiful weather. Hikes will also be offered Saturday at 3:00pm and on Sunday, August 19, at 11:00am, 1:00pm, and 2:00pm.

title: Ice Skating
details: Lynah Rink is the famous ice hockey arena where Cornell embarrasses ECAC opponents year after year. Many Cornellians get a chance to cheer on our Alma Mater as part of the 'Lynah Faithful.' Not many, however, get to skate on the ice themselves; here's your exclusive chance! Join us for fun skating, awesome music, and hot cocoa. Skate rentals and great memories are included.

title: Money Matters
details: This informative presentation will address topics ranging from bursar bills, the Cornell Card, and Big Red Bucks to general financial aid questions. Sponsored by the University Bursar, Campus Life, and the Office of Financial Aid and Student Employment.

title: Africana Studies and Research Center Open House
details: Join faculty and staff from the Africana Studies and Research Center to learn more about this multidisciplinary, academic unit dedicated to providing the highest-quality education, research, outreach, programs, and courses to the Cornell community on Africa, the Caribbean, and the United States.

title: German Placement and CASE Exams
location: Noyes Lodge Language Resource Center (near Beebe Lake)
details: See page 12 of the Orientation Guide for more information.

title: Ancient Greek Placement Exam
details: See page 12 of the Orientation Guide for more information.

title: Latin Placement Exam
details: See page 12 of the Orientation Guide for more information.

title: Library Tours of Olin, Kroch, and Uris
details: See page 54 of the Orientation Guide for more information.

title: Collegetown Tour
location: Collegetown, Meet in Front of the Schwartz Center
details: Collegetown is Cornell's hub of great restaurants, off-campus living, and more. Located just beyond Cornell'sSchwartz Center, this business district offers fine dining ranging from deep-dish pizzas at the Nines to authentic Korean BBQ at the Four Seasons. Experience first-hand the wealth of options Collegetown has to offer!

title: Using the TCAT Bus System
details: Sometimes campus can seem huge and finding your way around can get confusing. The TCAT bus service is a great way to travel across campus and into the greater Ithaca area. Head over to the Tatkon Center and learn the tips and tricks on getting from point A to B.

title: First Lecture Series: Separating the Facts from Fallacies Concerning Nutrition and Health
details: The annual First Lecture Series features a prominent Cornell faculty member delivering a first lecture to new students and parents. Join Professor David Levitsky as he explores the relationship between financial interests and nutrition. Where there is money, there is corruption. It is as true in nutrition as in any other area of human experience. Join him as he explores how large financial interests not only 'rip people off' but actually impede us from improving our health by optimizing our nutrient intake.

title: Chemistry 2070 (2090) Advanced Placement Exam
details: See page 10 of the Orientation Guide for more information.

title: Meeting with Lee Laoshi
location: Wendy Purcell Lounge, 203 Robert Purcell Community Center
details: Frances Yufen Lee Mehta will host this special meeting for Asian students and parents. This will be a great chance to find out about the dynamic activities of the Asian community at Cornell. Frances Yufen Lee Mehta is Faculty-in-Residence of Court-Kay-Bauer Hall.

title: Office of Academic Diversity Initiatives and Intercultural Center Orientation & Parents Panel
details: You are invited to attend this special session to learn about the many resources we provide to build community and support your academic success. Join our network of diverse students, faculty, and staff as we come together to honor your momentous new beginning!

title: Transfer Student Dinner
details: Join us for a dinner on West Campus to familiarize yourself with Cornell's nationally ranked dining rooms while also enjoying the company of new classmates. If you don't have a meal plan, your meal will be provided, just sign in at the door.

title: Gap-Year Student Meet-and-Greet
location: Wendy Purcell Lounge, 203 Robert Purcell Community Center
details: Did you take a year off before coming to Cornell? Join current gap-year students at this informal meet-and-greet, chat about your experiences, and share questions with other gap-year students.

title: Cornell University Glee Club and Chorus Orientation Week Concert
details: Take this opportunity to hear the Cornell University Chorus and Glee Club in concert! These student-governed vocal ensembles will perform a diverse choral repertoire as well as a rousing set of Cornell songs. A great opportunity to immerse yourself in Cornell's musical tradition.

title: Regional Receptions
location: Balch Courtyard near entrance to Carol Tatkon Center
details: Did you travel farther than a state bordering New York to make it all the way to Ithaca? Do you wonder if anyone from near your hometown or even your state made that journey too? Come snack on treats and find out at the Regional Receptions! You can also talk to current students from your area and hopefully learn some tricks of travel and transition. Rain location: Tatkon Center.

title: De-stress on West
location: Hans Bethe House, 2nd Floor Seminar Room
details: Nervous about starting classes? Don't let work get the best of you! Come listen to Haji Otto, leader of the 'Chill Out Revolution,' discuss stress-relief techniques that can be helpful while a student at Cornell. Let this guru teach you time management and relaxation methods that will keep you happy, healthy, and loving life.

title: Resident Advisor (RA) Meeting #2
location: North Campus and Collegetown Residents - See your RA for location
details: In this meeting you will get a chance to plan for the year with your residence hall community. Now is the time to get a jump on getting to know each other and build a community contract.

title: Transfer Orientation Leader Meeting #2
location: Location TBA at your First Night OL Meeting
details: Meet with your Orientation Group to touch base and go over important information. Additionally, you'll meet up with other OL groups during this time so that you meet other new transfer students from other colleges.

title: Orientation Leader Meeting #2
location: Location TBA at your First Night OL Meeting
details: Meet with your Orientation Group to touch base and go over important information. Additionally, you'll meet up with other OL groups during this time so that you meet new members of the Class of 2016 from other colleges.

title: Transfer Casino Night
details: Try your luck at blackjack, roulette, Texas hold 'em, and more! At this event, you will be able to meet other new transfer students while snacking on free hors d'oeuvres, drinking mocktails, and playing cards. Orientation volunteers will be there to teach beginners. The more you win, the more raffle tickets you can earn. At the end of the event, raffle tickets can be entered for a chance to win amazing prizes!

title: Great Migration
details: An Orientation Tradition! Walk to Barton Hall with your Orientation Group and the Class of 2016 to watch an astonishing performance by world-renowned performer Tim Gabrielson.

title: Movie Night
details: Tired from all the activities of Orientation Week? Perhaps enjoying a nice movie is just the way to lose out a full day of activities. Join your class on the slope to watch The Hunger Game and while you're at it, grab some popcorn and enjoy watching the stars...on screen that is.

title: Chemistry 2080 Advanced Placement Exam
details: See page 10 of the Orientation Guide for more information.

title: First-Year Writing Seminar Consultation
details: See page 6 of the Orientation Guide for more information.

details: This annual sale is a green way to stock up on items for your new room. Consider shopping here first and see what you can reuse to reduce harm to the environment. All proceeds go to charity.

title: Mathematics Advanced Placement Exam
details: See page 10 of the Orientation Guide for more information.

title: Music Advanced Placement Exam
details: See page 11 of the Orientation Guide for more information.

title: Take a Hike with Friends of the Gorge (throughout the day)
location: Meet outside the Tatkon Center, Balch Hall, Beebe Lake side
details: Cornell's campus is known for its natural beauty, but many students never get the chance to fully appreciate all the gorges have to offer. Join Friends of the Gorge on a scenic walk around Fall Creek Gorge and Beebe Lake. Come relax, meet some new people, explore your campus, and enjoy the beautiful weather. Additional times at 1:00pm and 2:00pm.

title: The Cheating Game
details: Do you still remember that student in high school who cheated and got away with it? Have you thought about your ability to do the right thing when faced with unforeseeable challenges in college? Come to this fun and fascinating session about cheating. You will learn some of the psychology behind cheating and some of the ethical dilemmas and temptations students face. Play some interesting cheating games and confidentially learn where you stand on the cheating scale. Lunch will be provided at this relaxed discussion.

title: Welcome Reception, Protestant Cooperative Ministry
details: A reception for students following the 11:00am Protestant worship service in the Anabel Taylor Hall Chapel.

title: Big Red Marching Band Auditions
details: Informal auditions for the only REAL marching band in the Ivy League! Meet current members. Any and all majors welcome. No experience necessary and school instruments are available to use. More information can be found online at mb.bigredbands.org.

title: Computer Science Advanced Placement Exam
details: See page 10 of the Orientation Guide for more information.

title: [MiXeD] Mixer: 1st Year Student Welcome Reception for Bi/Multi-Racial/Ethnic Students
details: Do you identify with more than one race or ethnicity? Feel like you navigate a bicultural world? Come connect with other students, staff, and faculty and learn about race-based support resources on campus. Open to all who want to create a positive space for bi/multiracial/ethnic individuals on campus.

title: First-Year Writing Seminar Consultation
details: See page 6 of the Orientation Guide for more information.

title: Four Steps to Happiness at Cornell
details: Start your college experience positively by learning the four concrete steps to 'happiness at Cornell!' The steps spell out the word S.O.A.P. but have nothing to do with being clean. We will be handing out some free soap and some brain stress busters to squish when your brain is too tired to think. Learn how to prevent stress, be academically and socially successful, and meet other students!

title: Cornell Traditions
details: Did you know that a Cornell alum invented air conditioning? Have you heard about the pumpkin that was stuck on top of the clock tower? If you want to learn more about Cornell's history, traditions, and alumni, come to Call Auditorium in Kennedy Hall for a presentation by Cornell's unofficial historian, Corey Earle '07!

title: Capture the Flag
details: Excited to hang out with all the new friends you have made during Orientation? How about some friendly competition? Get ready to enjoy the beautiful August weather while it lasts! Come to the Court-Kay-Bauer Quad to play an awesome game of capture the flag!

title: Trail Running in Ithaca
details: Some students run around Cornell for years not knowing that there are fantastic scenic trails just a stone's throw from campus. We will meet at Bartels Hall. Instructors will guide you on a gentle four-mile run past cliffs, over streams, and along winding paths. Meet other runners and discover some of our favorite places for a refreshing workout. Space is limited. Call us at 607.255.6183 to sign up.

title: Big Red Bowling
details: Got time to spare? If you're interested in food, fun, and games, then bowling is right up your alley!Show who's the real Lebowski by striking up a conversation or two while playing a few rounds ofBowling at Helen Newman! Games and rentals are on us.

title: Explore the Plantations
location: Cornell Plantations, meet at Appel Commons or at the Nevin Welcome Center
details: Come see how gorgeous Cornell really is and join us for a relaxing walk through Cornell Plantations' botanical garden! Guides will lead you on a 10-minute walk to the gardens beginning at 1:00pm from Appel Commons on North Campus. At 1:30pm you can take a one-hour guided tour through the botanical gardens. Don't have time for the full tour? Tour guides will also lead 15-minute mini tours of the gardens from 2:30pm to 3:15pm and be on hand to answer your questions. Bring your walking shoes and explore the beauty of Cornell Plantations!

title: Climb to the Top!
details: Come out to Bartels Hall and experience the Lindseth Climbing Wall under the supervision of Cornell Outdoor Education. Also, meet new friends while enjoying various activities such as soccer, dodge ball, and volleyball! Opportunities to rock climb will be first come, first serve, so don't miss out!

title: Sustainability at Cornell: The Big Red Is Going Green!
details: Cornell took a momentous step in 2011 by ending the use of coal on campus, just one part of the Climate Action Plan for achieving net zero carbon emissions by 2050. Join Mike Hoffmann, director of the Cornell University Agriculture Experiment Station, and student leaders of sustainability-related organizations to learn about how YOU can make a difference.

title: New Student Reading Project Contexts Presentations
details: Begin your intellectual life at Cornell on the New Student Reading Project book, The Life Before Us. All transfer students will attend the lecture in Bailey Hall, while all other students will receive their lecture location from their Resident Advisor (RA).

title: Annual Cornell University Block Party
details: Enjoy music, new friends, games, and the best that Cornell Dining has to offer! Rain location is inside Robert Purcell Community Center and Appel Commons.

title: Fall Sorority Recruitment Meet & Greet for Transfers
details: Transfer students have the opportunity to join Greek life during their first semester! Come learn about the opportunities available for transfers and meet representative members from Cornell's fall-recruiting Panhellenic Council and Multicultural Greek Letter Council Chapters. Appetizers will be available, and dress is casual.

title: Fall Fraternity Recruitment Meet & Greet for Transfers
details: Transfer students have the opportunity to join Greek life during their first semester! Come learn about the opportunities available for transfers and meet representative members from Cornell's fall-recruiting Interfraternity Council and Multicultural Greek Letter Council fraternity chapters. Appetizers will be available, and dress is casual.

title: Transfer Orientation Leader Meeting #3
location: Location TBA at your Second OL Meeting
details: Continue to get to know your Orientation Group better and receive helpful tips and information from your OL about academics, campus life, and the coming semester.

title: Cornell Cinema
details: Visit cinema.cornell.edu to see what FREE films Cornell Cinema has in store for you this week and beyond! Cornell Cinema is considered one of the best campus film exhibition programs in the country, showing a wide variety of films every month, including classics, world cinema, recent hits, and independent films. They also host visiting filmmakers and live music/film events. The regular student ticket price is just $5.50, and even cheaper if you buy a Cinema Six Pass for $25 (good for six admissions to regularly priced events and valid for a full year).

title: Arch Sings - Come Hear Cornell's Best A Cappella Groups
details:
Love to sing? Beat box? Rap? Come get a peek at the different a cappella groups at Cornell all throughout Orientation week! Meet current members, hear a few songs, and enjoy the music around campus.

7:00pm - 8:00pm: Balch Hall Arch: Hangovers and After Eight
7:30pm - 8:30pm: Baker Flagpole: The Chordials and Less than Three
8:00pm - 9:00pm: Court Sky Bridge: Absolute A Cappella and Key Elements
8:30pm - 9:30pm: Collegetown: Touchtones and Nothing but Treble

title: Dance Series - Come Dance with Cornell's Dance Groups
details:
Love to dance? Come for an informative and entertaining look at the different dance groups at Cornell throughout Orientation week. Meet current members, watch a variety of styles, and learn some moves!

Helen Newman Hall Dance Studio: Illuminations
Noyes Community Recreation Center Multipurpose Room: Cornell Ballroom Dance

title: Trivia
details: It's rumored that 40% of Cornellians meet their spouse or partner at Cornell, but it's true that 100% of people meet great friends at Cornell. Why not test these statistics while also testing your knowledge at pub-style Trivia with other new transfers. Winners will walk away with fantastic Cornell prizes.

title: Slam Poetry Showcase
details: Join us in the famous Bailey Hall for what may be the most memorable performances of your Cornell career. Come experience Slam Poetry, an energetic and innovative twist on the spoken word. Join your classmates in watching Yamatai, Cornell's taiko group perform, followed by two nationally acclaimed spoken word artists, Gabriela Garcia Medina and The Asia Project. Entertaining colleges everywhere, these slam poets will bring the humor, inspiration, and energy to pump up your week!

title: Silent Disco
details: Join us on the Arts Quad as we put a new spin on party rocking with our largest ever Silent Disco! At a Silent Disco, rather than using a traditional speaker system, the music is broadcasted directly to your ears through wireless headphones. The headphones have a multiple channel feature so you can switch between the beats of two of Cornell's finest DJs as they play the music you like best at this dance party event!

title: German CASE Make-up Exam
details: See page 12 of the Orientation Guide for more information.

title: Physics Advanced Placement Exam
details: See page 11 of the Orientation Guide for more information.

title: Welcome to Olin and Uris Libraries
details: See page 55 of the Orientation Guide for more information.

title: Library Tours of Olin, Kroch, and Uris
details: See page 54 of the Orientation Guide for more information.

title: Introduction to Library Research
details: See page 55 of the Orientation Guide for more information.

title: An Introduction to Research at Cornell University
details: Transfer students, join Laurel Southard, director of undergraduate research, to explore research opportunities across many academic fields and learn how to get started. Many undergrads do research outside of their major and college. No previous research experience is necessary.

title: Visit Bird Mecca!
location: Lewis Auditorium, G76 Goldwin Smith Hall
details: Come see and hear examples from the world's largest archive of animal sounds and video. Find out why Hollywood producers love us. Learn more about how you can visit us for a nature hike, take a field science course in Kenya, or do your DNA analysis on site. We'll serve pizza after a short film.

title: Asian/Asian American Welcome Reception
details: The Asian/Asian American community at Cornell boasts more than 44 spoken languages and 75+ student organizations. Come meet student leaders of these organizations, mingle with staff and faculty who support this community, watch cultural performances, and enjoy some ice cream.  Sponsored by the Cornell Asian Pacific Islander Student Union.

title: Blood, Booze, & Band Aids
details: College is an adventure! If you get hurt along the way, it's important to know how to help yourself and others. Cornell University Emergency Medical Services (EMS) is a student-run First Response Basic Life Support agency that provides FREE emergency care to the Cornell Community 24/7. Learn about the services we provide, how to join our team, and what you can do to help in an emergency.

title: Maps 101
details: See page 55 of the Orientation Guide for more information.

title: Explore Research Opportunities at Cornell
details: The Cornell Undergraduate Research Board (CURB) is a student-run organization devoted to fostering undergraduate research at Cornell. Join our panel discussion on the wide range of research being conducted by undergraduates at Cornell and strategies that students use to find research opportunities.

title: Library Technology Tools and More
details: See page 55 of the Orientation Guide for more information.

title: Net-Print 101 - Set Up Your Laptop and Print Your Summer Reading Assignment
details: Excited to print your first college assignment? Drop by the Carol Tatkon Center to learn about Cornell's Net-Print network, get your computer set up by CIT experts, and print your summer reading assignment.

title: Learning Strategies Center Open House: The Importance of Time Management
details: Come learn a simple and effective time management technique that's used by many successful Cornell students. This mini-workshop, which only takes 15 minutes, is led by Learning Strategies Center (LSC) tutors. Drop in any time between 1:00pm and 3:00pm; there will also be information available about the LSC's supplemental instruction, free tutoring, and study skills support.

title: Fondue Fiesta
details: Open to all transfer students looking to try a delicious treat, enjoy this reception-style event with chocolate fondue and cold drinks. Come try a chocolate covered potato chip, or make your own delicious concoction! It's a great way to meet your fellow transfer students while enjoying a tasty snack.

title: Introduction to American Academic Libraries
details: See page 55 of the Orientation Guide for more information.

title: Beyond Binaries: Identity and Sexuality with Robyn Ochs
location: Lewis Auditorium, G76 Goldwin Smith Hall
details: This program explores the landscape of sexual orientation. Like snowflakes, no two people are exactly alike, so how do we map this landscape and assign labels to our complicated and unique experiences? What is the relationship between experience and self-identity, between self-identity and the way we are 'read' by others, between gender identity and sexual orientation? In this interactive program we explore different experiences of identity, the complexity of attraction, and more.

title: How to Win an Argument: An Introduction to Debate & Rhetoric at Cornell
location: Kaufmann Auditorium, G64 Goldwin Smith Hall
details: Afraid of public speaking? Want to learn how to make convincing arguments? Cornell ILR Senior Lecturer and Director of Forensics Sam Nelson will introduce you to academic and extracurricular options on campus for improving your debate and public speaking skills. Afterwards, the Cornell Forensics Society, ranked the 5th best debate program in the world, will host a public debate featuring Cornell's top debaters.

title: Cornell's 161 Things to Do!
details: Ever hear about the 161 Things to Do? The Cornell Daily Sun has compiled a bucket list for Cornellians to complete throughout their four years (Why 161? It's the number of steps leading up to the McGraw Clock Tower). Start to check items off of your list by enjoying bubble tea, corn nuggets from The Nines, and a special performance by an a cappella group.

title: New Student Reading Project Small Group Discussions
location: Locations will be emailed to you and posted in your Residence Hall/also available online at: reading.cornell.edu
details: Meet with 10-15 fellow students, a faculty or staff member, and a returning student to discuss the New Student Reading Project book, The Life Before Us. To help facilitate discussion, please bring your written response. The responses will be collected by your discussion leader, who will not grade them, but will automatically enter them into a writing contest. The authors of the ten best short responses will each receive a prize of $200 toward the cost of books. Sponsored by the Office of the Provost and the Office of Student and Academic Services.

title: Orientation Leader Meeting #3 for First-Years
location: Location TBA at your Second OL Meeting
details: Continue to get to know your Orientation Group better and receive helpful tips and information from your OL about academics, campus life, and the coming semester. Plus, you will have a chance to explore Cornell and travel around campus!

title: Professor Dinner
details: Come dine with other new students and some of the best faculty members at Cornell in one of West Campus's award-winning dining halls. Join in lively conversation about campus life, academics, research, and other aspects of Cornell. If you don't have a meal plan, your meal will be provided; just sign in at the door!

title: The Spirit of Cornell!
details: Curious about your own faith? Looking for community? Questioning your beliefs? Wanting to learn more about yourself? Come learn about our more than 30 different religious organizations that range from African American Christian Worship to Zen Buddhism. Getting involved means you can participate in worship, spiritual practice, community, learning, individual support and counseling, community service, engagement, fun, and more! From Hillel's BBQ, Intervarsity's interactive art display, Protestant Cooperative Ministry's ice cream sandwiches to Lutheran Little Red Toolkits, there will be multiple opportunities to explore the many affiliated communities within Cornell United Religious Work.

title: Healthy Eating on Campus
location: North Star Dining at Appel Commons
details: Meet with Cornell Dining's nutritionist to learn about healthy dining on campus, find vegetarian and vegan places to eat, and discuss any special dietary needs.

title: International Affairs 101 - Your Guide to the World!
details: Have an interest in international affairs? Want to learn about current world issues? Come join the Cornell International Affairs Society in International Affairs 101 - Your Guide to the World! We'll be traveling around the world in under an hour (beat THAT Jules Verne), learning about various world issues. From the food crisis in the Horn of Africa, to the Arab Spring, tsunami impacts on Japan, transfer of power in the DPRK, and world impacts of the coming US elections, you will leave informed and ready to tackle the world's problems! Before solving world hunger, you can solve your own by enjoying refreshments. Join us on our journey around the world!

title: An Introduction to Risley Theatre
details: Want to learn more about student theatre opportunities on campus? Then head over to Risley Theatre for a brief introduction to the Risley fall season (Dr. Horrible Sing-a-long Blog and Little Shop of Horrors, just to name a few), meet the students who run the theatre, and hear from some theatre-oriented student organizations. Any questions you have about theater on campus will be answered, so be sure to come! Refreshments will be served - a total win-win situation!

title: Real Students, Reel Stories
details:
There are three sessions starting at 7:00pm, 8:00pm and 9:00pm. Hear from upper-class students about their own introduction to Cornell. Learn how to navigate the University, get connected, deal with setbacks, find balance, and take advantage of the multitude of campus resources available. All new students are required to attend this event:

Transfer students: attend at 7:00pm

First-year students attend at the following times:
If you live in Balch, Jameson, Risley, or the Latino Living Center (LLC): attend at 7:00pm
If you live in Dickson, Donlon, High Rise 5, Ecology House, Just About Music, or Ujamaa: attend at 8:00pm
If you live in Townhouses, Low Rises, Court-Kay-Bauer, Mews, Holland International Living Center, or Akwe:kon: attend at 9:00pm

title: Arch Sings
details:
7:30pm - 8:30pm: Baker Flagpole Callbaxx and Hangovers
8:00pm - 9:00pm: Court Sky Bridge, Class Notes and Key Elements
8:30pm - 9:30pm: Collegetown, Touchtones and Baraka Kwa Wimbo

title: Dance Series
details:
Helen Newman Hall Dance Studio: Big Red Raas
Noyes Community Recreation Center Multipurpose Room: BreakFree Dance
601 Willard Straight Hall: Shadows Dance Troupe

title: Childhood Regression
details: The 90s were a simpler time that we all miss, so come join us in the nostalgia and enjoy all the stuff you loved as a kid in the 90s (except for dial-up). Capri Sun? Hungry Hungry Hippos? *NSYNC? There will be enough food, games, and music to shake a hoola hoop at. If you like Rugrats, Furbies, and cereal commercials, then this is the place to be.

title: Big Red Blowout
details: Come show off your Big Red Spirit at Barton Hall while bouncing on giant inflatables, playing fun carnival games, and taking pictures in a photo booth! The fun activities don't stop there. You'll also have a chance to meet Cornell's athletic teams, receive free give-aways, and eat sno-cones, cotton candy, and more. You won't want to miss this event and your chance to receive your free class t-shirt!

title: Library Tours of Olin, Kroch, and Uris
details: See page 54 of the Orientation Guide for more information.

title: Introduction to Library Research
details: See page 55 of the Orientation Guide for more information.

title: Let's Explore Exploration!
details: Since emergence as a species, humans have made astounding journeys that we call exploration. Stone-age peoples encircled the earth and then medieval and Renaissance Europeans followed them to rediscover lands and riches in Asia, Africa, and the Americas. Today humans explore the depths of the sea and Mars. If this subject interests you, enroll in History of Exploration: Land, Sea, and Space with Professors Norton and Squires, fall 2012.

title: Your Genetic Ancestry and Medical Risks Revealed by Your Toothbrush
details: Do you have allergies to milk or wheat? Does a relative suffer from a genetic disease? Are you curious about your family's ancestry? Find out how analysis of your DNA from a toothbrush sample of spit can provide insight into these and many other questions. Explore the ethical, legal, and social challenges we all face as this genetic technology rapidly becomes available to anyone with $99. If these topics interest you, enroll in Personal Genomics with Professor Aquadro, spring 2013.

title: Latino Studies Program Open House
details: Bienvenidos! The Latino Studies Program (LSP) and the Latina/o Student Success Office (LSSO) invite you to stop by and enjoy some Latino cuisine and learn about our resources. We offer a wide range of courses with the opportunity to minor in Latino Studies, a library/study lounge, a computer lab with printing, a conference room for group study and meetings, academic advising services, a Friday with Faculty luncheon seminar, and more than 30 Latino student organizations in one friendly space. We look forward to meeting you.

title: Student Governance at Cornell
details: An information session for new students interested in student government on campus. Representatives from the Student Assembly, University Assembly, Class Councils, and the undergraduate Student-Elected Trustee will discuss the different ways to be a part of the legislative, advocacy, and programming work of elected student leaders on campus. Together the different organizations strive to represent students to President Skorton, the administration, and the Board of Trustees while creating initiatives and programming that enhance student life on campus.

title: It's Not Easy Being Green: The Intersection of Sustainability & Spirituality
location: One World Room, B21 Anabel Taylor Hall
details: Interested in community service and the larger implications of how it impacts the world? Curious about sustainability that encompasses not only stewardship of our planet but also how we view and care for ourselves? Come network (over a free lunch) with a variety of students and staff as we explore what is already going on here at Cornell. If you like what you see, get involved! If you feel something important is missing, let's create it! This event is a collaboration between Cornell United Religious Work, Hillel, the Public Service Center, the Sustainability Office, and Cornell Team and Leadership Center of Cornell Outdoor Education.

title: Language and International Studies Fair
location: Uris Hall Terrace, Mario Einaudi Center for International Studies, 1st Floor
details: Find out about Cornell's numerous language and international programs and discover the many options on campus and abroad. You can meet language teachers and representatives from the Einaudi Center, Cornell Abroad, the Language Resource Center, the Language Houses, international programs, and various area studies programs across the globe. They will answer your questions about language courses, travel opportunities, fellowships, minor and major programs, and study abroad.

title: Sing at Cornell
details: Love to sing? Join us for an introduction to the exciting and diverse world of singing at Cornell. Come hang out with members of the oldest and most acclaimed vocal ensembles at Cornell. Learn and perform a few songs with the groups, connect with other students with a similar passion for music, and find out anything you wanted to know about singing on campus.

title: Housing Beyond Your First Year
location: Lewis Auditorium, G76 Goldwin Smith Hall
details: There is plenty of quality housing available on-campus and in Ithaca. As a transfer student, it's important to look very carefully at all of the housing options available to you and not rush into signing a lease. Please attend this session to learn about all of the options available. Sponsored by the Housing Office and the Office of Fraternities, Sororities, and Independent Living.

title: South Asian Awareness Social
details: Share in Bengali, Indian, Hindu, Nepalese, Pakistani, Sikh, Sri Lankan or any South Asian heritage? Want to learn more about the South Asian/Asian American community at Cornell? Come by this social event to meet students, faculty, and staff and learn about campus resources that support this vibrant community. Refreshments will be served.

title: High Adventure with Cornell Outdoor Education (COE)
details: Join Cornell Outdoor Education on the Arts Quad for a chance to climb into some huge trees, ride a zipline, walk a tightrope, and try our mountain bike obstacle course.

title: Beebe Lake Canoeing
details: See the Fall Creek gorge from a new perspective! Take out a Cornell Outdoor Education canoe for a serene paddle from Beebe Lake up into Hemlock Gorge. All equipment is provided for free.

title: Library Tours of Olin, Kroch, and Uris
details: See page 54 of the Orientation Guide for more information.

title: The Cornell Daily Sun
details: Founded in 1880, The Cornell Daily Sun is one of the nation's oldest daily college newspapers. The Sun is entirely student-run, publishing Monday through Friday during the academic year. This session will explore the newspaper business in the 21st century from on-the-ground reporting, advertising sales, web and print design, and information technology management to how you can get involved.

title: Green Vendor Fest
details: Forgot to buy something for your dorm? Looking for some new clothes to show off your style at Cornell? You're in luck! Cornell has brought together some of the best and most sustainable vendors from around Ithaca to campus! This event will allow easy access to vendors such as the Farmers' Market and Trader K's, one of Ithaca's best stores for gently used clothing.

title: Learning Strategies Center Open House: The Importance of Time Management
details: Come learn a simple and effective time management technique that's used by many successful Cornell students. This mini-workshop, which only takes 15 minutes, is led by Learning Strategies Center (LSC) tutors. Drop in any time between 1:00pm and 3:00pm; there will also be information available about the LSC's supplemental instruction, free tutoring, and study skills support.

title: An Insider's Guide to Global Health Experiences
details: Interested in global health? Want to learn more about the global health minor? Cornell Health International will be hosting an interactive presentation where students will share their service learning experiences in countries such as Tanzania, Ecuador, South Africa, and Rwanda. Come learn how to get more involved in global health groups on campus! Light refreshments will be served.

title: Finding Art in the Plant World
details: Come discover the different ways in which plants can be used in/as art, and create something unique, too. We will explore the relationship between plants and art as a distinctive lens through which to view the world, as well as the impact engaging with this creatively has on your well-being, a perspective which may serve you for many years to come! If these topics interest you, enroll in the Art of Horticulture with Professor Eames-Sheavly, fall 2012.

title: Ethical Issues in Biomedical Research: Old Tensions and New Questions
location: Lewis Auditorium, G76 Goldwin Smith Hall
details: Is the use of embryonic stems cells ethical? Should we be able to choose the sex of our children? Do we have the right to choose to die? Who should decide and how? The world of medicine is changing rapidly, and complex issues arise in many contexts, from the basic interactions between doctor and patient to the highly publicized controversies that turn medicine into headline news. In this program we will discuss these and other controversial ethical problems. If these issues interest you, enroll in Ethical Issues in Health and Medicine with Professor Vogel, spring 2013.

title: Maps 101
details: See page 55 of the Orientation Guide for more information.

title: eLibrary Open House for Engineering, Math, and Physical Sciences Students
details: See page 55 of the Orientation Guide for more information.

title: Swim Test, Women only
details: See page 5 of the Orientation Guide for more information.

title: CU Engaged! Public Service and Service Learning Opportunities at Cornell
details: Learn about volunteer and service-learning opportunities at Cornell including how students can impact local and global communities through organizations, coursework, and independent research. Representatives from the Center for Community Engaged Learning and Research and the Cornell Public Service Center will be on hand to tell you about the many different ways you can participate in the community.

title: Don't Let Stress Manage You, Learn How to Manage Your Stress
location: Wendy Purcell Lounge, 203 Robert Purcell Community Center
details: Looking for fun ways to de-stress around campus? Concerned about where to look for a helping hand? Do you love playing games and winning prizes? Then come on over to this fun-filled event hosted by Gannett Health Center where they will give you tips on how to relax on campus, hand out nifty guidelines for dealing with all types of stress, and host a game show based on helpful knowledge hidden around Cornell!

title: Club Sports Fair
details: Don't want to be a varsity athlete but still want to play a competitive sport here at Cornell? Want to be a part of the second-largest student organization on campus with over 30 club sports to choose from? Come to the basketball courts at Helen Newman to meet current club sport student-athletes, get information about practices/games/tryouts, and see how many different club sports there are at Cornell.

title: International Student Orientation for Late Arrivals
details: This session is for all incoming international students who were unable to participate in the PREPARE pre-orientation program for undergraduates. Topics covered include essential immigration and legal information, guidelines on health and safety, and tips for academic success. Come and meet other new international students, and receive a warm welcome from the staff of the International Student and Scholars Office who will be available to answer your questions.

title: First-Year Fraternity and Sorority Meet and Greet
details: Are you interested in joining a fraternity or sorority in January? Come meet men and women from Interfraternity, Panhellenic, and Multicultural Greek Letter Council chapters on Cornell's campus. Learn about Cornell's policies and opportunities for first-year students. Dress is casual.

title: Southeast Asian Awareness Social
details: Share in Filipino, Vietnamese, Thai, Singaporean, Malaysian, and/or Indonesian heritage? Want to learn more about the Southeast Asian/Asian American community at Cornell? Come by this social event to meet students, faculty, and staff and learn about campus resources that support this vibrant community. Refreshments will be served.

title: Library Tours of Olin, Kroch, and Uris
details: See page 54 of the Orientation Guide for more information.

title: Schwartz Center Open House
details: Head over to the Schwartz Center to learn about different performance and media arts opportunities. Snack on food while mingling with faculty and students involved at the Schwartz Center. Learn about upcoming productions, auditions, classes, tech opportunities, student leadership opportunities, or anything else you're interested in!

title: Does Urban Life Affect Your Mind?
details: Are you interested in how the physical environment affects human behavior and health, as well as how human behavior and decisions affect the environment? Then attend this session where we will examine whether urban living changes your behavior and your personality. To put it differently, how does growing up in a city, a small town, or the countryside affect you? If you want to learn more about this subject, enroll in Introduction to Human-Environment Relations with Professor Evans, spring 2013.

title: The Spice of Life: Using Darwin to Meld Ecology with Chemistry
location: Lewis Auditorium, G76 Goldwin Smith Hall
details: Why are chilies so spicy? The answers lie in the chemical and evolutionary interactions among birds, rodents, plants, and microbes. This session will explore the natural basis of interactions among species, plant defenses, microbial warfare, and human pheromones. If this subject interests you, enroll in Chemical Ecology with Professors Agrawal, Kessler, Raguso, and Thaler, spring 2013.

title: Cornell Dining Chef Bake-Off and Cookie Tasting
details: Meet and greet the Executive Chefs of Cornell Dining! Enjoy complimentary samples of the Class of 2016 Cookie and milk, and vote for which cookie should be served on campus!

title: Transfer Orientation Leader Meeting #4
location: TBA at Your Third OL Meeting
details: Come to your final Orientation Group Meeting with any concerns or questions that you may still have. You have another opportunity to tie up loose ends and make last minute connections at the Just Desserts Session later tonight.

title: Community Center Programs' Declassified Cornell Survival Guide
details: What's the quickest way to the Ag Quad? How do you get to the mall, and what's in it anyway? Get a handout on acronyms like OADI, FWS, CTB, CTP, NCPC, CCP, CKB, etc. What meals can you eat, where, and when? Let the Community Center Programs' staff teach you things that will help you survive the first year of Cornell!

title: Study Skills
details: Worried about how to master the art of studying at Cornell? Students will share their own study skills and tips for succeeding at Cornell, and professionals will speak of the resources on campus. You'll leave with many of the tools necessary for managing your time and studying effectively for the coming semester. Don't forget to bring your planner!

title: Introduction to Library Research
details: See page 55 of the Orientation Guide for more information.

title: Four Steps to Happiness at Cornell
details: Start your college experience positively by learning the four concrete steps to 'Happiness at Cornell!' The steps spell out the word S.O.A.P. but have nothing to do with being clean. We will be handing out some free soap and some brain stress busters to squish when your brain is too tired to think. Learn how to prevent stress, be academically and socially successful, and meet other students.

title: Non-Traditional Student Meet-and-Greet
location: Office of Academic Diversity Initiatives, 200 Computing and Communications Center (CCC Building)
details: Join fellow non-traditional students in getting an insider's view of Cornell at this relaxed meet-and-greet. Current non-traditional students will be on hand to chat and share their experiences about student life, campus, and the Ithaca community.

title: 30-Minute Mann Library Tour
details: See page 54 of the Orientation Guide for more information.

title: Orientation Leader Meeting #4
location: Location TBA at your Third OL Meeting
details: Come to your final Orientation Leader Meeting with any concerns or questions that you may still have and then head to the class photo together.

title: Class of 2016 Photo
details: This is one picture you will not want to miss! Make sure you are a part of the Class of 2016 photo! Join all of your classmates in forming a picture that will last a lifetime. Come with your OL Group and a smile!

title: Class Council Welcome Reception
details: Welcome Class of 2016! Represent your class by joining the Class of 2016 Council. The Class Council program has a rich and deep history in providing events and activities for the class.

title: The dr T. projecT: a cornell hiTchhiker's guide to culTure
details: Join faculTy-in-residence and professor of near easTern sTudies, shawkat Toorawa, as he launches The Third season of the popular 'dr T. projecT' with 30 minuTes of culTure, Tea and shorTbread! Let dr T. Take you on a Tour of london with The rock group 'The clash,' of the delTa quadranT with species 8472, and of canTos That changed The world (and the afTerlife). Drop in on any Tuesday Thereafter at 5:00pm for jusT 30 minuTes of music (such as lady gaga or a. r. rahman), film clips (Tim burTon, sembene), words (causley, jahiz), art (sinan, frank lloyd wrighT) - and Tea and shorTbread.

title: German Placement Make-up Exam
details: See page 12 of the Orientation Guide for more information.

title: Touching Hip Hop: Examining the Beginnings
details: Hip-Hop is a cornerstone of music today, but four decades ago it was just getting its start in the Bronx. In this session you will learn about hip-hop music by examining original documents from the Kugelberg Collection, America's largest archive detailing early hip-hop history in the Bronx, ca. 1975-1985, which includes photographs of party scenes and cityscapes, as well as event flyers and vinyl LPs. If you want to learn more about these topics, enroll in Hip Hop: Beats, Rhymes, and Life, fall 2012.

title: The Connected World: Social Networks & Their Influence
details: What is the 'six degrees of separation' model? How have social networks like Facebook and Twitter influenced both everyday life and global politics? Join us as we explore social networks as they relate to game theory, social behavior and relationships, on-line media, financial markets, and the structure of social institutions. If these topics interest you, enroll in Networks with Professors Kleinberg and Tardos, fall 2012.

title: Music by the Cornell University Jazz Ensembles
location: 3rd Floor, Robert PurcellCommunity Center Marketplace Eatery
details: A jazz performance by members of the Cornell Jazz Ensembles. All first-year and transfer students with jazz experience are invited to sit in. All other students are invited to listen and enjoy.

title: Night at the Johnson
details: Come experience the wonder of the sculptures, paintings, and other fine artwork at Cornell's very own Herbert F. Johnson Museum of Art. Peruse pieces spanning many different cultures, grab a bite to eat, and enjoy the musical stylings of a DJ and a string quartet. Feel free to come in cocktail attire and remember to keep it classy, Cornell.

title: Improv Comedy
details: The show will feature performances from Cornell's best sketch comedy groups and brightest improv talent. The acts will turn the audience's suggestions into funny scenes, hilarious situations, and out-of-this-world characters. Come with some friends for this crack-up comedy event!

title: Just Desserts Session
details: All transfer students should come out and celebrate the last day of Orientation. You deserve it! Come celebrate and have fun with an open dessert buffet, music, and door prizes while you mingle with returning students and the Orientation staff. This is great opportunity to make last minute connections and get the real inside scoop on life at Cornell.

title: Classes Begin
details: Welcome to Cornell. Enjoy your classes!

title: Picnic on the Plaza
location: Ho Plaza (Rain location: Memorial Room, Willard Straight Hall)
details: Celebrate the first day of classes with a great free meal! Come meet your friends, professors, and Cornell staff for lunch. Chill out in the sun with everyone around you while listening to our very own a capella groups and Top 40 hits. The Cornell Big Red Bear mascot, Touchdown, will be there giving out hugs - bring a camera! With a classic summer theme, watermelons, cookies, and lemonade are a must, as well as many other side items. This year's picnic will be divided into three serving sessions, each with different entres. Serving times are tentatively 11:00am, 11:45am, and 12:30pm.

title: Japanese Animation Society Workshops
details: Come see why we're one of the longest-running anime clubs in the U.S.! Browse our extensive manga library, try your hand at making plastic models ('Plamo'), or attend a short workshop on making costumes from scratch! Costuming workshops run 25 minutes and start every half hour.

title: Cornell Muslims: Mingling & Game Night
details: The Committee for the Advancement of Muslim Culture (CAMC) and Muslim Educational and Cultural Association (MECA) are holding a bonding event for new students who identify with a Muslim background as well as students interested in the Muslim world. Regardless of your faith, join us for a fun opportunity to mingle with Cornell students and create great bonds. We will have a presentation about Muslim life on campus showcasing the diversity of Muslims at Cornell as well as available resources. A game night will follow that will allow students to get to know each other better and discuss topics of common interest.

title: Recess
details: Remember the good ol' days when the best part of your day was recess? Come relive them with Community Center Programs! We'll have lots of FREE activities such as kites, jump ropes, chalk, pot-a-plant, Zumba, and more.

title: Murder Mystery: An Evening with the Don
details: The wealthy and influential Giovanni family get together each year with new prospective members. However, something sinister lurks behind the curtains, and it is up to you to figure out what is going on. An Evening with the Don is a murder-mystery event, in which the characters(you, the attendees) attempt to find out the truth. Refreshments served. Feel free to dress up.

title: Flicks Across CU
details: Welcome Weekend and Cornell Cinema team up to present two FREE hit movie screenings. Visit cinema.cornell.edu for titles, times, and location. (While it was not possible to confirm The Avengers at press time, it is a very likely selection.) Second movie screening begins at 10:00pm.

title: Shuttle to Treman and Buttermilk Falls State Parks
location: Depart From North or West Campus
details: Enjoy open swimming below the waterfalls at two of Ithaca's most gorgeous parks. Free shuttles will depart from North Campus and West Campus from late morning through late afternoon, with return trips to campus throughout the day or on the last shuttle at 7:00pm. Please make sure to check out the details and exact shuttle schedule at cornellplantations.org/swim.

title: Wellness Fair
details: Wondering what Cornell can do to keep you happy and healthy? Yoga, meditation, and massage experts will be present. Cornell Dining's nutritionist will be available to answer your questions. Come try out aromatherapy, smoothie samples, and have a massage.

title: Casino Night
details: Kick off the school year by trying your luck at the infamous Casino Night! Join the throngs to play poker, blackjack, craps, roulette, bingo, and mahjong. Be dazzled by tricky magicians and try to out-dress each other based on this year's theme (look out for the posters). Enjoy breezy mocktails, a luxurious chocolate fountain, and unbelievably cool prizes - all for free!

title: Street Fair
location: Ho Plaza (Rain location: Willard Straight Hall)
details: Join Cornellians for a spectacular night event! We've got free popcorn, cotton candy, and more fun carnival foods. Play old-fashioned carnival games for a chance to win some great prizes. Plenty of artists including clowns, magicians, fortune tellers, face painters, and live bands are sure to entertain. Look out for posters closer to the event with updates about the theme and specific acts!

title: Shuttle to Treman and Buttermilk Falls State Parks

title: ClubFest: Student Activities Fair
details: ClubFest introduces the student body to 300 student groups, each showcasing what their club has to offer. And you won't want to miss some of our featured performances! Free entertainment and food will be provided. Look out for your favorite groups and discover new possibilities!

title: Bienvenidos BBQ
location: Latino Living Center Courtyard, Anna Comstock Hall
details: Come meet the students, staff/faculty, and organizations of Cornell's Latino/a Community. Enjoy free food and become acquainted with the Latino Living Center!

title: Mann Library New Student Welcome
details: See page 55 of the Orientation Guide for more information.

title: Fight or Flight? Safety Night
details: Meet the officers from the Cornell Police! Walk a straight line wearing beer-goggles. Learn self defense techniques. Learn about the Blue Light Bus system, Light Up Cornell, and the Women's Resource Center.

title: Arch Sings
details: Last Call and Nothing but Treble sing at the Balch Hall Arch

title: Home Speak
details: Do you miss the sounds of the language(s) spoken at home? Stop by to speak your native language or practice one with the Language House. Make connections with other language enthusiasts. All levels welcome.

details: Welcome to this College Special Event.

title: Dean's Welcome and Information Session for all First-Year Students
details: Overflow seating is available in Rockefeller Hall.

title: CALS Students Tour the Tatkon
details: This tour will be led by an upper-level student from your college and will include information about the many interesting programs that the Center offers students throughout the year. For more information on the Tatkon Center, please see page 62 in the Orientation Guide. There is a second tour at 2:30pm.

title: Pre-Medical/Pre-Dental Orientation for First-Year and Transfer Students: Preparing for Careers in Human Medicine: Physicians, Dentists, and Related Human Health Professions
details: Plan your first year to include academic and extracurricular requirements for professions in human medicine. Students preparing for careers in medicine and dentistry are expected to attend, but attendance does not constitute a commitment to this career. After August 29, 2012, audio available at career.cornell.edu. HCEC/audio.html. Please note this program is also offered on Monday, August 20, at 5:15pm; please see page 41 in the Orientation Guide.

title: Engineering Mathematics Advanced Standing Exam for Biological and Environmental Engineering Students

details: Meeting locations and times will be emailed. This is an important meeting for first-year and transfer students to get acquainted with their major departments, meet other students and staff, and schedule meetings with faculty advisors.

title: Optional Transfer Student Credit Evaluation, By Appointment Only
details: Individual meetings with college staff to review transfer credit, graduation requirements, and course enrollment. Schedule an appointment by emailing the CALS registrar's office at cals-studentservices@cornell.edu or requesting an appointment by phone 607.255.2257.

title: Mandatory Biology Meeting for First-Year Students
details: Faculty, staff, and student advisors will introduce first-year students to the Biology major and help with schedule planning. (Transfer students should attend Sunday's 1:00pm meeting.)

title: Dean's Convocation
details: Welcome and reception for new students and parents. You will meet the dean, college faculty and staff, department chairs, as well as other students and parents.

title: Dean's Reception
details: Welcome to this College Special Event.

title: Advising Briefing for First-Year and Transfer Students
details: This is an important, required introduction for students to their first semester in Architecture, Art, and Planning covering topics that include advising, AP/transfer credits, course enrollment, diversity programming, career services, and off-campus study.

title: Department Meetings
details:
You will meet with department faculty and staff to find out about first-year courses, equipment lists for studios, writing seminars, and other important information. You'll also meet your classmates.

Architecture Department Meeting, 157 E. Sibley Hall
Art Department Meeting, 324 Tjaden Hall
Urban and Regional Studies Meeting, 101 W. Sibley Hall

title: AAP Advising Open House
details: The AAP Advising Office, which includes academic advising, career services, and diversity and inclusiveness, is having an open house for all new AAP students. Please feel free to stop by and meet the staff.

title: AAP Students Tour the Tatkon
details: This tour will be led by an upper-level student from your college and will include information about the many interesting programs that the Center offers students throughout the year. For more information on the Tatkon Center, please see page 62 of the Orientation Guide for more information.

title: First-Year Student Briefing
details: Mandatory for all first-year students in Arts and Sciences.

title: Office of Academic Diversity Initiatives Orientation and Parents Panel
details: The Office of Academic Diversity Initiatives (OADI) and the Intercultural Center at 626 Thurston Avenue welcome new students and their families to the Cornell University community! You are invited to attend this special session to learn about the many resources we provide to build community and support your academic success. Join our network of diverse students, faculty, and staff as we come together to honor your momentous new beginning!

title: Special Topics Sessions
details: Throughout this period of the day, there will be a variety of information sessions devoted to specialized topics that affect your academic planning. Attend any that are relevant to your interests and needs. A finalized schedule will be available later in the summer.

title: Pre-Medical/Pre-Dental Orientation for First-Year and Transfer Students: Preparing for Careers in Human Medicine: Physicians, Dentists, and Related Human Health Professions
details: Plan your first year to include academic and extracurricular requirements for professions in human medicine. Students preparing for careers in medicine and dentistry are expected to attend, but attendance does not constitute a commitment to this career. After August 29, 2012, audio available at career.cornell.edu.HCEC/audio.html. Please note this program is also offered on Monday, August 20, at 5:15pm; please see page 45 of the Orientation Guide.

title: Pre-Law Orientation for First-Year and Transfer Students
location: Lewis Auditorium, G76 Goldwin Smith Hall
details: This session is designed to help you think about the ways you can prepare yourself for a career in law.

title: Study Abroad
details: If you are planning to study abroad as part of your Cornell education, or just thinking about the possibility, this session will give you all of the information you need to achieve your goals. Explore the worldwide options offered through Cornell Abroad, learn about options for study abroad in any major, the timing of study abroad, and language preparation to meet college requirements. Many destinations require at least two years of language study in advance, so make sure you have the information you need to plan successfully.

title: Meeting for Entering Transfer Students
location: Kaufmann Auditorium, G64 Goldwin Smith Hall
details: Welcome to this College Special Event.

title: Balancing Academics and Athletics
location: Lewis Auditorium, G76 Goldwin Smith Hall
details: Whether you are on a varsity athletic team or play sports at a recreational level, students in Arts and Sciences can face some special challenges in balancing those efforts with their academic work. This session will offer you some practical tips on how to make that balance work for you.

title: Getting Involved in Music and Theater at Cornell
details: There are lots of opportunities for you to be involved in musical groups and theatrical productions, even if you have no plans to major in either of those fields. In this session, faculty representatives from both Music and Performing and Media Arts will identify the range of options available to you and give you some guidance on how to get started.

title: Which Math?
details: Faculty from the Mathematics Department will speak on optimal placement in Cornell mathematics courses.

title: Biological Sciences: Mandatory Transfer Student Advising Meeting
details: Mandatory for transfer students planning to major in Biological Sciences. Meet with faculty, staff, and student advisors who will introduce you to the major and offer course selection advice.

title: Open House
details:
This is your chance to get information about subjects and particular courses you are interested in. When you arrive for the Open House, you will receive a list of all departments and programs represented at the Open House. At this special event, faculty representing every major and minor offered in the College will be present to talk with you - not only about your fall schedule, but also about courses or opportunities you might wish to explore later during your time at Cornell. Please take advantage of this unique opportunity to have meaningful discussions with faculty from every discipline.

Peer Advisors: Student peer advisors will be available on a walk-in basis throughout the Open House period.

Languages: For information about instruction in specific languages, contact the appropriate department:
Africana Studies and Research Center (Swahili, Yoruba, and Zulu)
Asian Studies (Bengali, Burmese, Chinese, Hindi, Indonesian, Japanese, Khmer, Korean, Nepali, Sanskrit, Sinhala, Tagalog, Thai, Urdu, and Vietnamese)
Classics (Latin and Greek)
Comparative Literature (Russian)
German Studies
Near Eastern Studies (Arabic, Hebrew, Persian, and Turkish)
Romance Studies (French, Italian, Portuguese, Spanish, Czech, Hungarian, Polish, Bosnian-Croatian-Serbian, and Ukrainian)

title: Study Abroad
details: If you are planning to study abroad as part of your Cornell education, or just thinking about the possibility, this session will give you all of the information you need to achieve your goals. Explore the worldwide options offered through Cornell Abroad, learn about options for study abroad in any major, the timing of study abroad, and language preparation to meet college requirements. Many destinations require at least two years of language study in advance, so make sure you have the information you need to plan successfully.

title: Information Session on Majoring in Physics
details: A Physics degree provides the ideal platform for which to pursue a career requiring quantitative reasoning and physical insight. Professor Erich Mueller will provide information about the Physics program at Cornell, highlighting the breadth of career paths and logistics related to the major. Upper-class students will share their perspectives as well.

title: Meet Your Advisor! (Throughout the day)
details: See your faculty advisor to discuss your academic plans. See the orientation/enrollment site as.cornell.edu/information/orientation/advisor.cfm for details on your appointment time and location. This is an important meeting for first-year and transfer students to get acquainted with their advisors and to finalize course schedules for the fall semester.

title: Mandatory Biology Meeting for First-Year Students
details: Faculty, staff, and student advisors will introduce first-year students to the Biology major and help with schedule planning. (Transfer students should attend Sunday's 1:00pm meeting.)

title: Meet with Peer Advisors
details: Peer advisor names and meeting locations will be mailed to first-year students during the summer. If you do not receive your assignment, a list will be available at the Arts and Sciences Open House, Sunday, August 19, and at the first-year student briefings throughout the weekend.

title: Diversity Programs Reception
details: Meet with assistant deans, faculty, and peer advisors from the College of Arts and Sciences.

title: Exploring Internships and Career Options
location: Kaufmann Auditorium, G64 Goldwin Smith Hall
details: Join Christa Downey, director of Arts & Sciences Career Services, to learn what you can do with your liberal arts degree. This open discussion will include information on exploring career options, connecting with alumni to learn more about the world of work, and identifying summer job and internship opportunities.

details: Plan your academic program to include requirements for veterinary school. Pre-vets are expected to attend, but attendance does not constitute a commitment to this career. Audio available at media.career.cornell.edu after August 29, 2012.

First-year students will be dismissed and escorted to their academic briefings by the Engineering Peer Advisors. Family members will remain in Barton Hall for the Family Briefing.

title: First-Year Academic Briefings
location: See Engineering Schedule of Orientation Events for Locations
details: An important information session at which first-year students will receive an overview of their first semester at Cornell. Curriculum requirements, course schedules, and advising will be discussed. An open question-and-answer period will continue through 12:00pm for interested students. (Schedule of events and locations available at the Welcome in Barton Hall.)

title: New Transfer Student Academic Briefing and Major Meeting
details: An important information session at which new transfer students will receive an overview of their first semester at Cornell. Curriculum requirements, course registration, and advising will be discussed. Representatives from each Engineering major will be on hand for break-out group discussions following the general overview. (Schedule of events and locations available at the Welcome in Barton Hall.)

title: Engineering Dessert Reception and Major Information Fair for New Students, Families, Faculty, Administrators, and Staff
details: Enjoy dessert and conversation with faculty, administrators, staff, and students from the College. Gather information about the twelve different undergraduate majors, co-curricular opportunities, and support services that are available to undergraduate Engineering students.

details: This is a voluntary exam for all Engineering first-year and transfer students who are seeking to earn credit for Math 1910 and/or Math 1920.
